The diagram also highlights three germ layers: endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm, each represented by different colors. Additional structures labeled in the diagram include "pouch," "cleft," and "membrane." These features are important during early development, contributing to various anatomical structures in the body.

ocr_text:
EMBRYOLOGY OF ESOPHAGUS

¢ Primitive gut tube forms during 4" week of
gestation.

¢ It is derived from incorporation of the dorsal
part of the definitive yolk sac into embryo due
to embryonic folding.
vlm_text:
EMBRYOLOGY OF ESOPHAGUS 
Primitive gut tube forms during 4th week of gestation. 
It is derived from incorporation of the dorsal part of the definitive yolk sac into embryo due to embryonic folding.

ocr_text:
¢ Primitive gut is divided into foregut,midgut and
hindgut.

¢ Laryngotracheal diverticulum develop in the
midline of the ventral wall of the foregut.

¢ The distal end enlarges to form lung buds,which
is separated from the foregut by tracheo-
esophageal folds.
vlm_text:

La ry ngo tracheal divert i cul um develop inthe mid line of the ventral wall of the fore gut. 
The distal end enlarges to form lung buds,which is separated from the fore gut by trach eo- esophageal folds.

vlm_text:
Primordial Gut 
This image is a diagram of an embryonic development stage. It illustrates various anatomical structures and regions in the developing embryo, including:

- **Stomodeum**: precursor to the mouth
- **Pharynx**: the throat region
- **Heart** and **Aorta**: early cardiovascular structures
- **Esophageal region**: part of the developing digestive tract
- **Gastric and duodenal region**: precursors to parts of the stomach and small intestine
- **Celiac artery, Superior mesenteric artery, Inferior mesenteric artery**: major blood vessels
- **Liver**: developing organ
- **Midgut** and **Hindgut**: sections of the embryonic digestive system
- **Yolk stalk and Vitelline artery**: related to nutrient supply in early development
- **Allantois and Cloaca**: related to waste elimination and urinary development
- **Cloacal membrane and Proctodeum**: involved in the formation of the anal and urogenital structures

This diagram is useful for understanding the early stages of human development.

vlm_text:
The image appears to be a diagram illustrating the early development of the respiratory system in an embryo. It shows two stages of development:

1. On the left, a lateral view from week 3 where the "respiratory diverticulum," also known as the lung bud, is developing. This structure will give rise to the respiratory tract.

2. On the right, a front view from week 4 highlighting the "tracheo-oesophageal septum," which separates the esophagus from the trachea. This septum is crucial in forming the distinct respiratory and digestive tracts. The yellow coloring is likely indicating surrounding tissues, while the blue represents the developing respiratory structures.
This image is a diagram illustrating the development of the respiratory system in an embryo at the end of week 4. It shows the pharynx, trachea, lung bud, and esophagus from a front view.

vlm_text: The image is an anatomical diagram showing the esophagus in relation to the human spine and thoracic structure. It details the different sections of the esophagus - cervical, upper thoracic, mid thoracic, and lower thoracic esophagus - as measured from the incisors (teeth). The vertebral levels (such as C3, C4, T1, T5, T10) are marked alongside the diagram to indicate the corresponding anatomy of the spine. The diagram also shows divisions of the esophagus into upper, middle, and lower thirds and references the cardioesophageal junction.

vlm_text: This image is an anatomical illustration focusing on the esophagus and its blood supply. It shows the esophagus in relation to surrounding structures such as the aorta, trachea, and various arteries. The image includes detailed labels pointing to various parts, including the cervical, thoracic, and abdominal parts of the esophagus. It also labels several arteries, including the common carotid artery, subclavian artery, bronchial arteries, and branches of the thoracic aorta, that are involved in supplying blood to the esophagus. The illustration aims to highlight the major arteries and branches that provide blood supply to the esophagus and possibly shared branches with other organs like the stomach. Additionally, the anatomical positions of the esophagus, diaphragm, and stomach are shown, with some text explaining possible variations in esophageal blood supply.

ocr_text:
VENOUS DRAINAGE

¢ Proximal & distal esophagus drains into azygous
veins.

¢ Mid-esophagus drains into collaterals of left
gastric vein,br. of portal vein.

¢ Submucosal connection between portal and
systemic venous system in distal esophagus form
esophageal varices in portal hypertension.

vlm_text: The image is a detailed anatomical illustration depicting the venous system of the human body, particularly focusing on the veins of the thoracic and abdominal regions. It includes labeled structures such as the internal jugular vein, subclavian vein, superior vena cava, azygos vein, and hemiazygos vein. It also shows the liver and associated veins such as the hepatic veins, hepatic portal vein, and inferior vena cava. Additionally, it includes parts of the stomach and spleen with their corresponding veins, such as the gastric veins and splenic vein. Smaller annotations highlight various intercostal veins, the esophageal venous plexus, and related anatomy around the diaphragm. A detailed view of the submucous venous plexus is also presented in a separate section.

This image is a labeled diagram of the human autonomic nervous system in the thoracic region. It shows various nerves and ganglia, including:

- Vagus nerve (X)
- Recurrent laryngeal nerves
- Right and left recurrent laryngeal nerves
- Superior, middle, and inferior cervical sympathetic ganglia
- Thoracic sympathetic trunk
- Esophageal plexus
- Cardiac, pulmonary, and celiac plexuses
- Greater splanchnic nerves

The diagram illustrates the connections and pathways of these nerves as they relate to structures such as the esophagus and heart.

vlm_text: The image is a detailed anatomical illustration of the lymphatic system in the human thoracic and upper abdominal regions. It shows various lymph nodes and structures, including the inferior deep cervical (internal jugular) nodes, thoracic duct, and different clusters of lymph nodes like paratracheal nodes, superior and inferior tracheobronchial nodes, posterior mediastinal nodes, intercostal nodes, juxtaoesophageal and superior phrenic nodes, left gastric nodes (cardiac nodes of the stomach), and celiac nodes. Additionally, the image includes major anatomical structures such as the heart and surrounding blood vessels, portions of the lungs, esophagus, trachea, diaphragm, and segments of the spinal column and ribs, providing context for the positioning of these lymph nodes.

The right image is a lateral view, showing the cervical spine from the side. TECHNIQUE

PHARYNX

density(250% w/v).

swallowing there after.

ESOPHAGUS
Single contrast

Suspension given.

contraction.

compression, displacement or disordered
motility.
vlm_text:
ESOPHAGUS 
Single contrast -Multiple mouthful 80%w/vbarium suspension given. -prone swallow to assess esophageal contraction. -useful  in esophageal compression, displacement or disordered motility.

ocr_text:
Double contrast
-Contrast high density,low viscosity(200-250%).
-15-20 ml given & asked to swallow.

-Then effervescent powder given with another
mouthful of barium.

-In erect posture,gas tend to stay up so
adequate distention stays longer time.
Inj.buscopan I|.V given before the procedure to
keep esophagus distended for longer time.

GASTRO ESOPHAGEAL REFLUX

SIPHON TEST
Fill the stomach with 50% barium(150-200ml)

Follow this 1-2 mouthful of water to remove traces of
barium in esophagus

Pt in supine with left side raised 15% up
Keep one mouthful of water in pt mouth

water column as it enter GO junction

Alternatively with full stomach,ask pt to roll side to
side

Reflux will be seen
